title: Able to log in with default ██████g creds at  https█████████████████████.mil
content:
Summary████
was able to use ████████████████████████ to log into this instance of Adobe Experience Manager, though it does not seem to be in used at the moment
Description███████
while navigating to https█████████████████████████.mil, I performed some fuzzing and found that /repository was available which asked for authentication using ███████████████████ worked and I could then access another path found by fuzing lc https%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88.mil/lc which then showed me the ██████ panel.
Impact
Medium since it is not being used
## Step-by-step Reproduction Instructions
Navigate to https████████████████.mil/repository
use ████████████████ (username██████████password)
navigate to https██████████████████████.mil/lc
Product, Version, and Configuration (If applicable)
Adobe Experience Manager
Suggested Mitigation/Remediation Actions
Remove this application if it is not being used
Impact
Medium - I was able to use █████████████ to log in
Thanks
weaknesses: Information Exposure Through an Error Message
steps: Access the Adobe Experience Manager repository
Navigate to https██████████████████████.mil/lc to view the ██████ panel
vuln_description: The vulnerability allows unauthorized access to an Adobe Experience Manager instance using default credentials. The tester discovered this by fuzzing paths (/repository and /lc) and using common/default credentials to gain access to the system's administrative interface.
reason: The attack involves basic fuzzing techniques and the use of default credentials, which are well-known and commonly documented. There are no complex interactions or state manipulations required, and the vulnerability follows a straightforward pattern seen in many systems with default credentials.
